title: we must stop letting violent offenders like ewan ireland out with no restrictions its plain madness
story: Tony Blair’s infamous Antisocial Behaviour Orders were supposed to stop troublemakers causing misery for the public but ended up being broken with impunity and worn as a badge of honour by their recipients.But you may not have heard the letters RUI, standing for Released Under Investigation.If not, you soon will be hearing about them. RUIs are what the Law Society’s head of justice has described as a “major scandal” waiting to erupt.I know Home Secretary Priti Patel will have a lot on her plate as Parliament begins, but this ought to be one of her top priorities.The shocking overuse of RUI came to light on Wednesday, after -year-old thug Ewan Ireland was jailed for le for the murder of solicitor Peter Duncan in a Newcastle shopping centre in August.Peter’s misfortune was to have brushed past Ireland in the doorway of a shop, an act which Ireland took as a slight.He took hold of the screwdriver he had stolen minutes earlier and drove it into Mr Duncan’s heart.It is a tale of mindless, casual violence which has become all too common in modern Britain as the jumped-up egos of young men rage against anyone who gets in their way.But what makes it all the more disturbing is that Ireland’s tendency for extreme violence was well known to police and the courts, yet still he was allowed to walk the streets.While other boys of his age are busy studying for A-levels, Ireland had already amassed a formidable range of criminal qualications.He had  convictions for  dferent offences. He was on conditional discharge for an offence of battery and on bail for a charge of affray for threatening to slash another boy’s Achilles’ tendon.Yet in spite of all this, he had been released under investigation for a robbery.He is not the only violent criminal to have been sent on his way by police. In September last year Alan Martin, of Sunderland, was released by police after his estranged we accused him of raping her.Not only did officers release him, they also ed to him the keys to his we’s house. He promptly ed to the address, attacked her with a hammer and strangled her before taking his own le, too.Astonishingly, Northumbria Police were later cleared by the Independent Office for Police Conduct. No one seems to want to take responsibility. No doubt it will be the same next time, too.Since April , , violent criminals have been released under investigation, Home Office figures reveal.Unlike police bail, no restrictions have been placed on these people. They are not banned from visiting particular places, they have not had to raise a deposit, hand over their passport or report to police at regular intervals. Nor, unlike police bail, is there any time limit on RUI, so police are under no pressure to bring charges quickly.The misuse of RUI is a hangover from Amber Rudd’s time as Home Secretary. It was her Policing and Crime Act  which stopped police putting people on bail for periods of more than  days. True, something needed to be done. The case of former Radio  DJ Paul Gambaccini had inspired the rule change.He had been held on bail for a whole year as police investigated accusations of historic sex offences which turned out to be without foundation.Unable to put criminals on bail for more than  days, police forces took to releasing them under investigation instead.That might be perfectly reasonable in the case of relatively minor crimes which take a long time to investigate, but it is hardly an appropriate way to treat suspected murderers and rapists, especially those with a long history of violent offences.At the very least, people suspected of violent offences — and for which good evidence exists that those offences really did take place — need to be monitored.As for people who have been released on licence while serving sentences for previous convictions, there should be no argument at all — they should be taken back to prison without hesitation.Ministers like to talk tough on crime, especially around election time, but behind the scenes they get caught in the stranglehold of the liberal establishment.Punishments get weakened, prisoners get released early.Disgracefully, former Home Secretary Jack Straw described the sentencing system as the “benign deception of the public”, who, unaware of the soft reality, assume that criminals are being properly punished.But there is nothing benign about serial offenders being freed to rape and murder when police and the courts know full well their records.During the election campaign, Boris Johnson finally called an end to the deception.Braving an onslaught from the nation’s liberal consciences, he announced that prisoners will no longer be eligible for automatic early release — something which allowed the London Bridge killer Usman Khan to embark on his murderous spree.But the Johnson Government should not end there.It needs to stop the police releasing violent offenders back into the community without any restrictions on their movements nor any requirement ever to report to a police station.Liberals like to say that we can’t solve crime just by jailing people. On the contrary, had Ewan Ireland been kept out of circulation after his first offence it would alone have meant  fewer crimes in Newcastle over the past four years.It is hard enough to catch criminals.But to release those we do catch, giving them the freedom to embark on long crime sprees, is plain madness.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 6 hangover cures christmas
story: Thats a lot of sore heads over the course of a week.And while theres no instant miracle cure just yet, there are few things you can do to alleviate those awful hangover symptoms.The key is to focus on replacing the essential vitamins and minerals your entire day drinking wiped out in a flash.But first, its worth understanding exactly what a hangover is - aside from a sign you had a little too much the night before.Nutritionist Amanda Hamilton explains that its a whole series of things that combine to drain our bodies of all the goodness they need.A hangover is a combination of toxin overload coupled with dehydration and vitamin depletion, caused by that harmless one too many, she told The Sun.All alcohol contains toxins and, in fact, the whole experience of getting intoxicated is simply giving your body so many toxins that it cant process them quickly enough.So, how do we get rid of that dreadful feeling Here are just some of the ways you can give your hangover a kicking...It may seem a little obvious, but try and stay hydrated throughout the day, making sure you get the daily two to three litres.Another trick that can be really helpful is to have a large glass of water before you start drinking.Minerals are easily lost in sweat and urine - soyoure going to be doing a lot of dancing or constantly nipping to the loo then its good to give yourself a head start on the hydration stations.Amanda said: Sip throughout the day, aiming for approximately two litres each day, but remember you’ll get some of this from food.Keep urine straw coloured as the yardstick of being well hydrated.Alcohol is a diuretic, making you pee often and ultimately leading to dehydration.Although dehydration is not considered a main cause of hangovers, it may contribute to symptoms like thirst, headache, fatigue and dry mouth.That is why there is no harm in downing a pint of water before you go to sleep.This will help top up your hydration levels, to lessen or even stop that imminent pounding head.They say a cup of tea solves everything.And Amanda says thatyoure feeling a little worse for wear, caffeine might be a good idea for a hangover.If you need to be mentally sharp, try coconut oil in a boosting coffee, she said.Herbal teas, like ginger tea can take the edge of the nausea.While milk thistle tea cleanses the battered liver, while hot water with honey and lemon can help boost blood sugar levels.Eastern Europeans and Russians are renowned for their drinking ability so they should have a good cure too, right In the midst of bleak Baltic winter, vodka-swiggers swear by drinking pickle juice — which allegedly replenishes the electrolytes your body lost the night before and perks you up a bit.Just don’t forget to pinch your nose.Its probably the last thing you want to do, especially at this time of year.Butyou make sure you’ve rehydrated a bit of light exercise sparks up your metabolism and releases endorphins.Amanda said: If you want to feel more alert, fitting in short high intensity interval training can help.It won’t speed up the rate that alcohol is metabolised or detoxied but the endorphin release can boost your mood.Just keep water handy so you don’t become even more dehydrated.If you really have over done it and simply cant face the day, getting plenty of rest is your best bet.If nothing  works, magnesium salts for a long, hot bath and go back to bed, Amanda added.Last but not least,you’ve partied the whole night then try to repay the sleep debt quickly.Research published in the American Journal of Physiology showed that six nights of sleep deprivation has a negative effect on attention, inflammation as well as impacting on will power - not helpful for the next time the mince pies come around.Of course the best way to avoid a hangover is simple - dont drink.But at Christmas time that can be easier said that done.If you are going to indulge in a few festive tipples then make sure you eat plenty too.And what with all the turkey, stuffing and puddings, we dont think that should be too hard.Amanda said: Alcohol dfuses through the walls of the stomach very quickly soyou havent eaten for a while, it will enter your bloodstream and be absorbed into your body faster.The best choice of food before drinking is something that has a healthy fat content to help slow down the rate at which food leaves the stomach.Our title: joe biden stutter sarah huckabee sanders
story: Sarah Huckabee Sanders faced backlash after posting about the former US Vice Presidents delivery during Thursdays Democratic debate.Sanders wrote in a since-deleted tweet “I I I I I I I I I I I I I I I hhhave absolutely no idea what Biden is talking about,” as the debate was wrapping up.Biden, a  frontrunner, had been discussing children who suffer from speech impediments when he made the stumble.Within moments, critics slammed Sanders for her comment.Sabrina Singh, a National Press Secretary for Cory Booker tweeted: This is the most disgusting tweet of the night.While Biden staff campaigner Andrew Yates wrote: An insultingly stupid whopper from Sarah Huckabee Sanders — now I’ve seen everything.Toward the end of the debate, Biden spoke about the people he meets while campaigning, who ask him for help.He said:“My we and I have a call list of somewhere between  and  people.I give them my personal phone number.”Biden then spoke of a “little kid” who approached him and said: “I can’t talk, what do I do ”He then appeared to impersonate the child’s stutter.Later, Sanders took yet another jab at Biden, tweeting: “Simply pointing out I can’t follow much of anything Biden is talking about.”Biden then pointed out his battle with the speech disorder, tweeting: I’ve worked my whole le to overcome a stutter. Look it up.Sanders then apologised, claiming she was unaware of Bidens condition.Stuttering and stammering are actually just the same thing, they refer to a relatively common speech problem in childhood which can persist into adulthood.A stammer can present itself in a few ways it can cause the person to repeat syllables, make words sound much longer or sometimes words can get stuck and not come out at all.It can y in its severity in dferent people, some who are barely affected at all while others can find the condition debilitating.It’s hard to say what causes children to start stammering but the NHS reassures parents that it won’t be caused by anything they have done.They explain that the development of speech is complicated and depends on many factors and that problems can occur when parts of this developing system aren’t quite coordinated.There are a number of dferent speech and language therapies for those who struggle with a stammer and each child would have their own tailor made treatment plan.These could include creating a more relaxed environment to build the child’s confidence and working on the feeling associated with stammering like fear and anxiety.“I actually didn’t know that about you and that is commendable,” she wrote. “I apologize and should have made my point respectfully.”In a recent interview with the Atlantic, Biden recalled his boyhood efforts to overcome his speech impediment.It doesn’t—can’t define who you are, Biden said to The Atlantic.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: christmas never same without mum
story: NewsChristmas will never be the same without mum - but well celebrate for her this yearMatthew Scotts mum Sharon loved everything about Christmas and he remembers her dancing in the kitchen singing her favourite festive songs at the top of her voiceShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsMatthew with his mum Sharon at her favourite time of the year" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf youaposre lucky enough to have the people you love most in the world around you, Christmas is a time of happiness and joy. But for people dealing with grief, the festivities often bring a new wave of pain and heartbreak. TV producer Matthew Scott lost his mum Sharon  months ago and was dreading his first Christmas without her last year. He made excuses when friends asked him out for drinks, wiped the Christmas songs from his playlists and said the day itself just felt wrong. But this year things are going to be dferent. While the Scott family accept that Christmas will never be the same, they know how much their mum loved the festivities. So this year, theyaposre going to celebrate - because itaposs what she would have wanted. Here, Matthew explains what itaposs really like to deal with unimaginable grief at this time of year. --- Every year until last Christmas, a parcel would arrive for me on November th, A-sized and rather thin. The advent calendar, sent from mum without fail. But now I buy my own. A reminder of being without my mother aged . It’s been  months this December since mum passed away from secondary breast cancer. She was . For many, Christmas is the most wonderful time of the year. Music fills the air, it’s a time meant for joyous celebration with friends and family. But for me it’s also the season for intensied grief. And I’m not alone. Cruse Bereavement care saw a % increase in December helpline calls compared to  while , Samaritans volunteers responded to an average of  calls for help each from people feeling overwhelmed on th December. Mum loved Christmas. It was at Christmas that she excelled herself. She brought the family together. For the last few years of her le, I’d count down the days until I’d speed along the M from London back to rural Herefordshire, playing Chris Rea’s Driving Home for Christmas.  I’d arrive to boxes and boxes of chocolates that mum claimed were untouchable because they were “for Christmas Day”. And yet we were still eating them in January. Mum would get me up at the crack of dawn and shout “wakey wakey, it’s Christmaaaaas!. Even in our s, my sister and I would wait at the top of the stairs while mum would “checkSanta’s been” before we could come down. It wasn’t Christmas without her gravy with a secret spoonful of cranberry sauce for sweetness, stirred to the beat of Michael Bublé. She would dance around the kitchen, singing at the top of her voice while the dog would go mad. Mum was the most selfless woman. I remember we once met an old man in a café who lived alone. Mum got chatting and wanted to invite him round on Christmas day.  When she got her five-year all clear from cancer the first time around, she told me how she felt a new lease of le. How every flower seemed brighter, like she was living le in HD. Mum knew that le was precious. I was  when she passed in July last year. She got ill again very quickly and from her diagnosis to her death it was just six weeks.  My sister and I slept by her side in Cheltenham hospital every night during the final weeks. With things deteriorating rapidly, the three of us moved to a local hospice. From then on, time felt irrelevant. In a strange way, those last few days were the most therapeutic. It was just us, no distractions, no doctors reporting results every four hours. I remember singing to her in bed as she slowly smiled, eyes shut. The feeling of not wanting to waste a moment together tiptoes on the edge of never knowing when the final moment will come. But it did. I think about her death every day. Navigating the world since then has felt like I’m in a trance. I used to phone mum every day on my walk home from work. Sometimes we’d just stay on the phone together, not saying much. For a while I still called her number. At first, losing her felt like the end of my s. It aged me. Responsibility for my sister, my nan, and our dog Archie fell to me. I am estranged from my father, but mum and I were incredibly close. The paperwork that comes with someone passing is always overwhelming but aged , combined with losing someone who was my main support system, it was excruciating.  Just when you think you are coping well, a season or anniversary approaches and the memories take you right back to where you started. Last Christmas, the first one without my mum, my coping mechanism was to ignore the festive spirit. I made excuses to friends when asked to meet up for a mulled wine and Mariah Carey was removed from Spoty. On the day itself, my sister and I woke up in the family home and the rooms felt cold and empty. We laid a wreath on mum’s grave on Christmas morning and stopped quietly for a short while. We didn’t say much all day. Lunch was at my auntie’s but the atmosphere, the food and the exchanging of presents all felt wrong. It just wasn’t Christmas. But this year will be dferent. Mum loved Christmas and she would want us to fall back in love with it. So we will. We will get out her favourite baubles that she carefully bubble-wrapped, we will iron the Christmas tablecloth, white with embroidered holly leaves, and we will make her gravy.  My sister, a -year-old NHS nurse who cared for my mum devotedly, has to work on Christmas day so we’ll make merry a day late on Boxing Day. We’ve invited our nan and we’ll lay a place for mum and grandad, who we also lost months after mum. We can’t forget they aren’t here, so we will include them. I am by no means finished with grief. My mind runs wild with regret, missed opportunities, things I wish we’d done or said together. Grief is unfixable. It doesn’t heal.

title: conman photographer who lured women
story: NewsConman photographer who lured women into fake porn shoots found guilty of rapePaul Brown, who operated under the  name of Paul Smart, set up a bogus modelling agency which he used to manipulate his victims who he raped at his Okehampton studioShareByTed Davenport:,  DEC NewsConvicted rapist Paul Brown - who operated under the  name Paul Smart" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA conman photographer has been found guilty of raping, abusing, or spying on  models who posed for him at his studio. Paul Brown deceived the women into believing they could be glamour or adult starsthey stripped off or joined him in casting couch sex sessions. He set up a bogus modelling agency which he pretended had nothing to do with him and which he actually controlled and used to manipulate the victims. The models thought the agency was genuine and could find them work but onlythey went for apostest shootsapos at his studio in Okehampton, where he operated under the  name of Paul D Smart. Brown invented two fictional women, who supposedly ran the Models South West agency. Brown, through the agency contacted many of the victims of Facebook, told them they had the potential to be models, and inviting them to the studio.  Once they were there, he persuaded some to have sex with him on camera and others to strip for what he called aposartistic nudeapos sessions where he in fact focussed his camera on their private parts. The rape victims were told they could earn large amounts by posing for a type of pornography called POV or point of view, in which the participants film themselves having sex. They all thought the material would be sent to the agency Model South West, which would find them work. In reality, the agency was a sham and Brown kept the images for his own sexual gratication. Some of the models who had sex with him were lured back to his studio on the Fatherford Farm trading estate in Okehampton by messages from the modelling agency saying the scenes had to be re-shot. One model who was reluctant to strip naked heard Brown call Model South West and pretend to have a conversation with the agency about how she was ideal for nude work. The models came from all over Devon and were of all ages and sizes, ranging from their late teens to their s, Many were vulnerable and insecure about their bodies and were fooled by Brownaposs smooth talking and flattery. None of them ever received any offers of work and none of them received any of the money which he promised would follow. Brown kept a record of his sexual conquests in a aposblack bookapos which recorded details of some of the rape victims. The book contained the names, ages, physical details of Brownaposs partners and included a mark out of ten for their performance. The book even included his own we, who scored nine out of ten. The whole set up with the agency was a device to con women into satisfying his sexual appetite, which was described as sleazy and sordid by the prosecution. Brown joked with police in one interview that he was not Harvey Weinstein but employed a classic casting couch technique of offering fame and fortune in exchange for sex. The couch actually came from Ikea. He set himself up as a photographer despite having little formal training and a background as an IT adviser, at one stage working for the NHS in Exeter. Brown committed the offences while running his studio at the Fatherford Farm trading estate in Okehampton between  and . The police were first alerted in  by one of the rape victims who went to a genuine modelling shoot with a professional photographer a few days afterwards.  She realised that what Brown had done amounted to a sexual assault and went to the police, who arrested him and seized the black book. He carried on in exactly the same way while he was being investigated by police and went on to rape another two women. Brown was found guilty of  out of  charges including  rapes against six dferent women. He was also found guilty of voyeurism against five other women. He pleaded guilty to one count of voyeurism, which involved him installing a hidden camera at his home to spy on a young female visitor in the bathroom. He was cleared of four counts of sexual assault, which alleged that he touched models while rubbing oil onto their bodies during shoots. Brown, aged , of Okehampton, denied a total of  rapes against seven women, four of sexual assault against four women, and six of voyeurism against six women. He said all the women consented to what he did, in many cases in advance and in writing. He was found guilty of  rapes and five counts of voyeurism and remanded in custody by Judge David Evans, who adjourned sentence until February. He put Brown on the sex offenders register and ordered the probation service to prepare a report of whether Brown is a dangerous offender. He told him:You have been convicted of many of these serious offences and in due course you will be sentenced to a signicant time in custody. The appropriate time will only be decided in the light of the relevant material.

title: doctor turned comic adam kay
story: NewsDoctor-turned-comic Adam Kay on working Christmas Day in NHS emergency departmentExclusive: Adam Kay has revealed what its like to work the seven Christmas Days in an NHS AE with emotions running high over death, birth - and extraordinary festive outfitsShareCommentsByLila Randall:,  DEC NewsDuty calls for Adam, pictured in the operating theatre" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDoctor-turned-comic Adam Kay was on duty across six Christmases in his years with his beloved National Health Service. His festive experiences ranged from the painfully tragic to the downright bizarre. Now the best-selling author of Diaries of a Junior Doctor has written a new book capturing the highs and lows of having to work while many of us are celebrating. In his first book Adam told how punishing long hours on the ward forced him to quit the vocation he cherished. These extracts from Twas The Nightsht Before Christmas, again based on his diaries, are equally funny, thoughtful and searingly honest. Here are some of his best bits The NHS front line sadly doesn’t get invited to Christ’s all-you-can-eat birthday shindig. For medical personnel the world over, Christmas is just another day. Employees vy up the shts and put in absurdly unsociable hours to ensure the rest of us make it through to the New Year in one piece. Of the seven Christmas Days I was a practising doctor, I ended up on the wards for six of them – removing babies and baubles from the ious places they found themselves stuck. Dec ,  Sharing what I think is a top-level anecdote in the doctors’ mess. I’m delighted with my story of the -year-old whose half-a***d attempt at a costume for his Christmas party landed him in AE. He had wrapped himself in layer upon layer of tinfoil, made a couple of holes for his eyes and one for his mouth, then dispatched himself to the party as a turkey. Hours later he collapsed, having desiccated himself to the human equivalent of a Ryvita and needed intravenous rehydration. Xmas Day  Santa might be putting his feet up but his pal the Grim Reaper never gets the day off. And so I find myself in a side room with a distressed family having The Chat about mum gran. Granny is outnumbered by E.coli bacteria in her bloodstream to the tune of several billion to one and there’s now only one way this can end. Hoping to show empathy through my body language, I lean in to say all we can do now is keep her comfortable and concentrate on her dignity. As I do so, I inadvertently lean on my tie. It’s a seasonal tie – a night-sky blue with old Santa on his sleigh perched right up near the knot. Moving down the tie we come to Prancer and Dancer and the rest of the reindeer massive with Rudolph proudly front and centre.  Crucially, and disastrously, underneath Rudolph’s red nose – and now the pressure of my elbow – is a button that activates a tinny speaker to blast out a frantic rendition of Jingle Bells. I turn ketchup red, apologise and jab at my abdomen. But all I succeed in doing is restarting the f***ing tune. Thinking of superlatives to add to my apologies, I notice one daughter laughing uncontrollably. Maybe there is an easier way to deliver bad news, after all. New Year’s Eve,  I meet Patient AW who prepared for the new year with a bang. Followed by a whimper. Finding herself in a suitor’s bedroom, in need of lubrication, she went to the kitchen and re­­­turned with a tub of peanut butter.  It wasn’t the most terrible choice – it’s oil-based, plus it offers the option of smooth or crunchy for added “pleasure”. Downsides include the fact that oil-based lubricants are kryptonite to condoms. Also, some people have peanut allergies. Patient AW, for example. But whyyyy ’ I asked, stret­ching the word longer than Annie Lennox ever managed.“I assumed it was only a problem, you know, up the other end,” she explained. Luckily, she escaped the worst-case scenario of breathing dficulties and ultimately not breathing at all. Xmas Day  Despite my best efforts it’s a hat-trick: three Christmases on the trot opening up patients instead of presents. I’m bleeped away to see Patient NW who has come to labour ward with reduced fetal movements at  weeks. And the baby’s breech – so caesarean section it is. “Oh, for f***’s sake,” she says.  I reassure her everything’s going to be absolutely fine. “Oh, it’s not that,” she groans. “My other one was born on Christ­­mas Day too. Everyone’s going to think I do this deliberately to save on presents.” Dec   And then there’s Patient KM, a lady in her s, about to kill herself with sharon fruits. A decade or so ago KM had a gastrectomy for stomach cancer and now has to keep to a strict diet, avoiding certain food types she can’t digest. Top of the list is the persimmon or sharon fruit – not exactly a Granny Smith so an easy fruit to avoid. You might think. Grow­ing up in Malta, KM’s family Christmas always involved eating sharon fruits and this isn’t a tradition she is prepared to let slide, despite her surgeon’s threats. She knew it wasn’t an idle threat either these little f***ers have caused five episodes of intestinal obstruction, ruining five Christmases. “It just wouldn’t be Christmas without it,” she tells me. I’m not sure whether she’s talking about the fruit or her hospital admission for intestinal obstruction. Dec   Medical emergencies don’t get any less frequent just because Slade is belting out of every shop’s PA system. Prof Devereux’s termination of pregnancy list is too time-sensitive for a week off. I’m rota’d into theatre with Prof today and first on the list is Patient SH whose unbelievably sad story is the stuff of ethics textbooks.  She’s  and has a cardiac condition that means she’s unlikely to liveshe continues with her pregnancy. At  weeks her hearthas already signicantly deteriorated and she’s had to make the heartbreaking decision to end the pregnancy to save her own le. Prof Devereux, chatting to the anaesthetist about who got treated the worst by the Christmas Rota Fairy, turns to me and asks: “Do you want to do it ” I really, really don’t. The procedure is going to be grim beyond words – one more trauma for me to push down into a box that’s already full to bursting. ButSH is brave enough to go through this then I should at least have the balls to step up for her. I wish I could say I was overreacting but the truth is that every single step of it was absolutely horrible. I’m jolted back into the here and now by Prof Dev­ereux. “Right, we’re done!” he bouncily announces. “Who’s the next customer ” I say: “I need to head back to the ward.” But I don’t. I need fresh air or a quiet room. Even a noisy room – any room that isn’t this one. Jan ,  “I don’t want to die,” Patient JM said, plaintively. None of us wants to die, of course – it’s human nature – but I was surprised to hear it from a -year-old.  We’re conditioned to describe this as a good innings. I decided the best thing was pretend I hadn’t heard and continued to insert the drip. She touched my hand. “Is this it ” she asked, her eyes searching mine. “Am I dying ” She knew. And she was dying – it wouldn’t be more than a day. I’d never been asked this before and I had no idea how to deal with it. I copped out and lied: “No, don’t be silly!” Not just “No” but “No, don’t be silly!” – negating her, throwing her off the scent, in reply to the bravest question of all. She pretended to accept my answer with a faint smile. I realise I never actually talk about death with patients. For the rest of the night sht I obsess over what I should have said. At the end of the sht I trudge back to her ward. I tell myself I’m going to speak to her again, giving myself a motivational pep talk as I go. You’ve got this, I say, you owe it to her. There’s an empty bed in bay three. I don’t have to. Xmas Eve  Patient HL presents with post-coital bleeding. Inside, everything looks a bit... grazed. There’s clearly a piece of her story missing. The actual answer is that, with no condoms available, she and her fella dipped into a selection box and improvised with a Mars bar wrapper – really embracing the “play” aspect of “work, rest and play”. I advise less abrasive methods of contraception and, until it has totally healed, to take a break. By which I don’t mean she should move on to KitKats.

title: ex liverpool wag turned jihadi
story: NewsEx Liverpool WAG turned jihadi bride is jailed for sending money to ISIS fighter husbandFormer Miss Teen GB contestant Amaani Noor, who was in a long-term relationship with Liverpool and Rangers footballer Sheyi Ojo, sent money overseas to a jihadist fighter who she married onlineShareCommentsByEleanor BarlowJoseph WilkesReporter:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsFormer beauty queen Amaani Noor,  " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA beauty queen and ex-girlfriend of a Liverpool footballer has been jailed for  months after she sent  to her jihadi fighter husband she met online. Amaani Noor, , who had planned to join her Islamist fighter husband in Syria, has been found guilty of fundraising for terrorism. She was wooed online by aposHakim My Loveapos and told him Itaposs been my dream to marry a fighter for a long time and my dream to be a fighter myself even longer. She also communicated with mum-of-two Victoria Webster, , and accessed video footage showing torture, beheadings and people being set on fire which the judge described as truly shocking. Webster was also sentenced at Liverpool Crown Court today. Noor, of Cinema Drive in Wavertree, Liverpool, had claimed she believed  dollars, around £, she donated to the Mercul Hands organisation on May  last year would go to buy food for women and children in Syria. But earlier this month a jury found her guilty of fundraising contrary to the Terrorism Act . Webster, of Pine Street in Nelson, Lancashire, was jailed for  months after she pleaded guilty at an earlier hearing to two counts of providing money for the purposes of terrorism and one count of inviting another to provide money for the purposes of terrorism. Serena Gates, prosecuting, said Webster donated a total of about £ in a series of small amounts. Both women were in tears as they were told they would be jailed. Sentencing Noor, honorary recorder of Liverpool Judge Andrew Menary QC rejected the claim that the former performing arts student had set up a PayPal account in a fake name because of considerations of modesty. He said: I donapost accept simply that you are that modest or naive in the way you would like people to believe.  I have no doubt your commitment to your religion is entirely genuine but sadly there is a cunning about you which you maintained during your evidence. During the trial, the jury heard Noor, a former Miss Teen GB semi-finalist, and Webster messaged using the Telegram app and spoke about extremist groups including so-called Islamic State . They had access to video footage showing torture, beheadings and people being set on fire which the judge described as truly shocking. Noor, who wore a black hijab, also used the app to message a man named Hakim My Love who, she told the court, she had married over videolink and who described himself as an independent fighter in Syria.  On the day officers searched her house, in July , she had a ticket booked to travel to Turkey. The court was read emails found on a phone seized by police, believed to be written by Noor to Hakim, which said: Itaposs been my dream to marry a fighter for a long time and my dream to be a fighter myself even longer lol. The jury was told Noor had been in a relationship with a professional footballer when she was a teenager and also had a short marriage to a preacher. The player was not named, but Noor dated Sheyi Ojo who is currently on loan at Rangers.  David Gottlieb, defending, suggested her failed relationships may have led to the offences and sent her spinning out of the solar system. He said she was in a new relationship and her fiance was in court along with her brother and mother. Mr Gottlieb said: She needs to address issues of self-esteem and making relationships. Hossein Zahir, defending Webster, who wore a pink niqab, said she was on a path to reform. He added: The ideology she thought she believed in has left her le in ruins. He said she was influenced by Kamran Awan, who was connected to the Mercul Hands, and had been cynically used by him.

story: NewsGerman Shepherd has major surgery after eating ft of Christmas tinselThe eight-year-old dog, Benji, is recovering and his injuries are healing well after having surgery in Manchester - but a leading vet is warning of the dangers of pets eating tinselShareCommentsByEmily Chudy:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe dog has recovered from major surgery in Manchester " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA German Shepherd had to have major surgery after eating three feet of Christmas tinsel. Eight-year-old dog Benji has recovered from the procedure in Manchester and is back home with his injuries healing well. But a leading vet is warning of the dangers of pets swallowing tinsel over the festive period. Benji was taken for X-rays by owner Olivia Mullen, an animal care assistant, which showed cm of tinsel inside the dogaposs stomach. Ms Mullen, , said: This is the first time heaposs ever done anything like this. He doesnapost even go after shoes or toys, so it was a total surprise. The tree wasnapost up yet and he had actually gone rooting through a box. I was working and my mum called me to say he had eaten some tinsel. I see poorly animals on a daily basis at work, but when it came to my own dog, I was an absolute mess ... I was so upset and worried, but I knew he was in the best possible hands. David Owen, lead emergency vet at Vets Nowaposs Manchester hospital, said: Shiny tinsel can be very attractive to both dogs and cats but, like anything stringy, itaposs extremely dangerousswallowed.  In veterinary medicine, we call this a linear foreign body. If the tinsel anchors itself in the stomach, it canapost then pass through the intestines and can slowly cut through the tissue like cheese wire. Ethical vegan Jordi Casamitjana only dates other vegans, doesnapost sit on leather sofas and doesnapost allow guests carrying animal products into his home. The campaigner is launching a landmark case in an attempt to get ethical veganism added to a list of protected characteristics enshrined in equalities law, in a bid to officially protect vegans from aposdiscriminationapos. The Mirror can today reveal his legal team plans to compare veganism to religious evangelism as one of its key arguments planned for the two-day employment tribunal pre-hearing on January . Mr Casmitjana plans to argue that the vegan movementaposs tendency to try to convert more people to the lestyle means it should be legally recognised as a aposphilosophy and belief systemapos. He will even produce receipts for vegan shoes and aftershave in court in his bid to argue that veganism is not just a diet- but a belief shared by a growing number of people in the UK. The trained zoologist is originally from Catalonia, but has lived in the UK for  years, and has had a long career in animal protection. He identies as an aposethical veganapos. Dietary vegans and ethical vegans both eat a plant-based diet, but ethical vegans also try to avoid any animal exploitation, such as by shunning clothing made of wool or leather and not using products tested on animals. Mr Casamitjanaaposs legal battle began last year after he was sacked from his job with the League Against Cruel Sports after disclosing to other employees that its pension funds invested in firms involved in animal testing. He claims he was sacked as a result of his ethical vegan beliefs. But the organisation has rejected his claims, previously telling the BBC he was dismissed for gross misconduct. The allegations will be dealt with separately in another employment tribunal hearing later next year. A spokesperson told the Mirror: “The League Against Cruel Sports is an inclusive employer and as this is a hearing to decide whether veganism should be a protected status, something which the League does not contest, it would be inappropriate for us to comment further.”  Veganism aposlike a religionapos Vegan activists and legal eagles are closely watching the case, sayingMr Casamitjanaaposs wins it could set a signicant precedent.  But some commentators worryhe wins his case, it could open up the floodgates to other lestyles receiving legal protections that could have a aposchilling effectapos on free speech in the UKaposs workplaces. Mr Casamitjanaaposs key argument is that veganism should be treated as a belief because it reaches into every aspect of his le, and is a lestyle shared by a growing number of Brits. His legal team will present philosophical statements arguing that veganism is morally necessary. It will also all argue that the value he and other activists value place in persuading others to become vegan to increase followers of the lestyle cements its status as a belief system- not just a dietary or consumer choice. His side will also argue the world is becoming increasingly aware and accommodating of vegans.  Mr Casamitjana told the Mirror: “Currently many vegans feel discriminated against, despite the growth of the movement. “If I am successful I hope it will make other vegans feel more confident expressing their beliefs and helping raise awareness for other people to consider this way of living and ensure all ethical vegans are better protected from discrimination. The impact of securing legal protection for ethical vegans in the UK is likely to generate ripples in other countries, potentially sparking new legal protection for vegans where.  “This can only have a positive impact on animals, the environment and public health. Veganism a growing trend The case comes as veganismaposs popularity rises, with the number of consumers around the UK following a plant-based diet quadrupling between  to .  Marketers have leapt on the growing trend, with the range of vegan products on offer in supermarkets and eateries booming nationwide in recent years. According to the Vegan Society, , people in the UK identied as vegans this year- amounting to . per cent of the population - and up from , people in . The society said it is not just vegans driving the change, as supermarkets and restaurants race to cater to the one in three Brits who say they have consciously cut down on meat, dairy and eggs.  The society is backing Mr Casamitjana, whose crowdfunding campaign for his legal battle had reached nearly £, this week. Spokeswoman Dominika Piasecka said: “While veganism clearly meets the requirements for being considered a philosophical belief protected under the Equality Act , this has not been proven in court yet.  “We are eagerly awaiting the outcome of next year’s hearing which we expect will favourably clary the legal status of veganism. “This isn’t of course just about the rights of vegans a society that respects veganism and accommodates vegans also gives expression to the undisputed moral standing and rights of non-human animals.” What is a protected characteristic  The Equalities Act  protects people from discrimination and harassment in their workplace, and when they are using private or public services, on the basis of any of nine protected characteristics. They are: age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sex, and sexual orientation. Mr Casamitjanaaposs lawyer Peter Daly, of Slater and Gordon called it a ground breaking case. This case is important not only for Jordi, but the wider vegan community in the UK and globally.  Ethical Veganism is a whole philosophy which guides all of Jordi’s choices from the products he buys, to the transportation he uses and where he invests his money.  We are hoping this hearing will support our view in Jordi’s belief system as similar to a religion and a special characteristic deserving of protection. A aposslippery slopeapos The tribunal will have to decide whether veganism, like religion, meets a series of thresholds that would see it treated as a philosophical belief worthy of protection under the Equality Act .  Nick Spencer, a senior fellow at thinktank Theos, commended Mr Casamitjana for his commitment to his ethical beliefs, but worriedhe wins his case it could transform a moral issue into a legal one. He labelled the case a “slippery slope.” “The concern is that it could have a chilling effectyou’re running a workplace and you have a vegan there you could be very cautious, very concerned that anything you did or say or opinion you gave -they took offence - it could become a legal issue.

Footage shows Liam Cornett cruising around in flashy cars and playing with money during a luxury holiday to the state.The -year-old, nicknamed ‘the Lam’, flew in a helicopter and drove around Monte Carlo in a convertible Bentley with his right hand man Michael Rice, Liverpool Echo reports. Cornett - who exploited vulnerable people to sell drugs - has been jailed for  years today. He was sentenced along with  other offenders involved in a large-scale drug dealing network. Cornett ran the network along with Micheal Rice, , from Liverpool and Kieran Eves, , from Hale, who were jailed for  years and  years respectively. Cornett and Rice funded their lavish lestyle via the massive drugs operation they oversaw. Cornett, who had a home in Huyton, controlled the importation of cocaine, heroin and amphetamines into the UK. Rice oversaw the day-to-day operation on the ground, controlling drugs from their arrival in England to the distribution of the substances and sales all the way down to the streets of Anfield, Hull and Exeter. Riceaposs sentence was added to a six year term already handed out for possession of a handgun.Cornett was described as a “constant thorn in the communities of Merseyside” at an intelligence briefing before his allies were targeted in dawn raids across the UK. Dozens of Merseyside Police officers listened as the North West Regional Organised Crime Unit detailed the targets of Operation Valkyrie in December . Most already knew his name. As he climbed the criminal hierarchy, Cornett’s identity became entwined with the exploits of Liverpool’s underworld. Cornett, who bought a home on Roby Road in Huyton, clocked up a record of dishonesty offences as a teenager before being jailed for affray in .  Yet it was his activity abroad that saw him climb to become one of the most signicant players in the latest generation of Merseyside’s criminal fraternity. In , Cornett was jailed in the Netherlands for crimes that effectively equated to attempted murder, threats to kill and causing grievous bodily harm. The convictions arose from an incident in which he drove at a police officer. The attack was not publicised because Dutch courts do not name defendants. But it was known in police and criminal circles on Merseyside - as was the three year sentence he received.  Cornett eventually based himself in Spain, where he made contacts that gave him to access drugs there and in North Africa. He then organised their importation into the UK and the Netherlands. When he was questioned over the investigation that led to him being jailed this week, he did not deny he was a drug dealer - he instead argued the drug lines he oversaw related to cannabis, not Class A substances. At Cornett’s sentencing hearing in Liverpool Crown Court, Henry Riding, prosecuting, said: “Liam Cornett has a home in Spain. It is common ground that for a number of years he has been involved in criminal activity in Spain, including the organisation of importations of controlled drugs into the UK and Holland from Spain and North Africa. “His evidence was that it was exclusively Class B drugs and that he organised importations both for his own operations and on behalf of other organised crime groups.”  He was not charged in relation to any cannabis conspiracy but Mr Riding said the claims were relevant because they confirmed “he is a sophisticated and experienced criminal who is well-versed in the techniques of drug supply”. The December  raids that shattered his network were the climax of Operation Anvil, which had begun in the summer of , when Cornett was living on the Costa del Sol. By this stage the drug supply lines he controlled in Liverpool. The profits funded a playboy lestyle that saw him in party in one of the world’s most glamorous playgrounds - Monte Carlo, where he flew in a helicopter, rode in a convertible Bentley and was filmed throwing wads of cash in the air. That holiday on the Mediterranean took place in the summer of  and during the opening months of Operation Anvil.  Not content with the huge sums already available to him, around the same time he made extensive efforts to expand his network. In August, September  - apart from the Monte Carlo trip - and October of that year Cornett spent much of his time in the UK plotting new hubs for his enterprise to exploit. First Cardf, where the gang sent amphetamines, then Exeter, where the Liverpool outfit simply took over the local trade and Plymouth, where they teamed up with a prominent local enforcer to sell cocaine and heroin. Cornett would travel to meetings between top-level associates as he agreed the terms under which he would supply his drugs.  Often, detectives tracked lower-ranking figures of his as they travelled separately, sometimes, by train, carrying samples used to entice prospective gangland partners. Once established, Cornett would play a hands-off role on the operations, allowing trusted associates to control the graft phone lines used by addicts to order their fix. From June  to August  the phone number that controlled the Liverpool dealing operation received , calls. From May to July  the Hull line received , calls and in Exeter the phone number received , calls in its first week alone. Detectives from NWROCU teamed up with those from forces on the south coast to bring Cornett down. Undercover police officers posing as drug users captured details about how the gang worked on the ground. Meanwhile, a massive surveillance operation captured snapshots of the gang’s exploits.  In the summer of , Cornett spent nine days in a Dutch prison after ing to the country for a music event and being picked out as an “undesirable alien”. Calls from jail made to his right hand man, Michael Rice, were recorded and revealed him ordering for the network to “stand still”. In November  one of his contacts had his suitcase searched ahead of a flight from John Lennon Airport to Spain. Inside was £,, thought to be destined for Cornett. Police were also aware of him spending £, on a new Audi during the course of their surveillance. In December , Rice was stopped by armed police in an Audi. He was in possession of a Glock handgun and jailed for six years as a result. Despite the capture of his closest associate, Cornett remained active.

A study of , adults explored exactly what we love most about the holidays - with Christmas jumpers, mince pies and putting up the tree also making the list. This time of year is also special thanks to festive movies, giving and receiving gts, and the chance to catch-up with relatives you donapost see very often. But with the excitement of the holidays, the Bupa care home research found itaposs all too easy for those polled to forget those less fortunate than themselves. Three quarters admitted they get so caught up with all the hubbub of Yuletide they have been guilty of not considering the plight of others. And as many as a third have felt lonely at Christmas at one time or another. To help tackle the issue, more than  Bupa care homes will open their doors on December  - welcoming older people who might otherwise spend the day alone. Joan Elliott, managing director of Bupa Care Services, said: While mince pies and presents will always be festive favourites, itaposs being with friends and family that really makes Christmas Day so special. But not everyone is so lucky and, particularly for older people, thereaposs a risk of spending Christmas by themselves. The study revealed that the Christmas spirit appears to be alive and well in other areas though with  per cent saying the true meaning of Christmas is to spend it with others. Half would consider having socially isolated members of the community over for a festive feast and three in  will check in with elderly neighbours during the holidays to make sure they are okay. In addition to looking out for one another, food is a crucial part of Christmas, according to those polled via OnePoll.Pigs in blankets, turkey and eating lots of chocolate all featured in the top  best things about this time of year. The mum - tormented by her fianceaposs coercive abuse - suffered a breakdown of such severity that she turned on her innocent son James and stabbed him to death.She then tried to take her own le too. The young family, living in Wythenshawe, Manchester, who had outwardly had seemed to have the world at their feet, was completely destroyed. What started as a whirlwind romance ended with a two-year-old boy dead, his mother jailed for  years for his manslaughter, and his father, Peter Chilvers, yesterday jailed for  months for the domestic abuse which triggered her breakdown.  A court has now heard how Lesicka was subjected to a relentless psychological abuse by Chilvers, a Ryanair pilot.She felt trapped her in a toxic relationship where his cruel, degrading torment drove her to desperation, reports the Manchester Evening News. Chilvers had inflicted a campaign of cruelty against Lesicka, forcing her into degrading sexual acts and into eating hairs he plucked from his head, while he had an affair with another flight attendant, who is mother to his two young daughters. A aposcontrolling monsterapos aposMagdaapos, as she was known to friends, had been a confident young air stewardess when she first met Chilvers, an ambitious young pilot, in . The pair had fallen for each other at their work Christmas party in Germany, when both were working for Ryanair.  After he attended her th birthday party, they chatted on Facebook and slept together for the first time. Soon flight attendant Lesicka and Chilvers were wrapped up love and the lestyle of travel that came with their jobs. Within weeks they had moved in together, and it wasnapost long before Chilvers, the son of retired teachers, soon began to show a bullying side to his character. The first sign came after a drunken night out. Chilvers had vomited everywhere so Lesicka slept on the sofa, to avoid getting any sick on her. When he woke up, Chilvers accused her of not loving him, shouted at her, slammed the doors and banged on a wall. Lesicka ended up apologising to him. It was, prosecutors would later say after their relationship had unravelled with such horrendous consequences, an early indication of the behaviour Chilvers would use to aposintimidate and controlapos Lesicka. He would become, in her words, aposa controlling monsterapos.  It had meant everything to Peter Chilvers to become a pilot. His family had made huge sacrices to help him achieve his dream. As he put it, aposthey all really believed in me and I wanted to succeed in leapos. His parents re-mortgaged their home to help pay the £, it cost to qualy, and his grandmother lent him some of her le savings. Chilvers, originally from Stoke-on-Trent, had first become interested in flying as a teenager who was into gliding. He went on to study modern history and international relations at university, and during his studies the advice of a family friend made him set on becoming a pilot. By January  he and Magdalena Lesicka were aposhead over heels in loveapos.  But when they moved to the UK, Lesicka began to feel more isolated, being further away from her family in her native Poland. She had got a staff transfer after Chilvers moved to Liverpool for work, moving in with him to a caravan in Frodsham, Cheshire, and then a nearby rental cottage, as they embarked on a new le together. But, as time wore on, Chilvers behaviour towards his partner got worse and worse. Prosecutors would later tell how he aposrepeatedly mistreated and bullied her at ever increasing levels to see what he could get away withapos. There was irrational jealousy, picking fights, accusing her of being apostoo friendlyapos with other men when they went out. There was casual sadism, like pinching her - or suddenly holding her nose and mouth, as they kissed, so she couldnapost breathe, only releasing his grip as she squirmed in distress. And there were his rages, with Chilvers backing Lesicka into a corner, banging the wall above her head with his fist as she cowered. He would blame her for these things - or deny anything had happened. Peter Chilvers treated Magda Lesicka asshe was a possession to do with as he pleased, Rob Hall, the prosecutor in his trial said.  A troubled engagement Despite all this, both seemed set on further committment. One day Chilvers took Lesicka to a beauty spot beside Coniston Water, a favourite destination of his family growing up. After a walk there, Chilvers decided to apospop the questionapos, but the moment was killed, according to him, when she said, aposI hope you are not going to propose to meapos. Nonetheless, on February , , a leap year, the day traditionally women propose to men, Lesicka decided to propose to him - hoping marriage would improve things between them. Chilvers accepted, but did not tell his family of the proposal for nine months, something that made her feel like she wasnapost good enough for him. They bought custom made rings from a jewellers in Krakow. But they would never marry. After finding the proposal had not improved their relationship, Lesicka decided to apply for another job. She moved to Dubai, with Chilvers insisting that she only stay for six months. They met up around the world when they could, and jurors heard that the long-distance relationship seemed to suit them better. But when Lesicka ed, they moved to Stoke and Chilversapos controlling behaviour continued.  In  Lesicka got a new job, working for Cross Country Trains, based at Piccadilly station in Manchester. Their relationship was still a dficult one, made worse by Chilversapos affair with his collague. Lesicka found out, and she broke up with him. What she didnapost realise at that time was that she had fallen pregnant with Chilversapos child. Chilvers was angered by the news and demanded that Lesicka have an abortion. On the phone from a holiday in New Zealand with his parents, Chilvers said having a baby would aposruin his career and leapos. In messages, he called Lesicka a aposmonsterapos, a aposbitchapos and a aposselfish c**tapos for wanting to have the baby. The response from Peter Chilvers was to send her a draft legal contract that outlined their responsibilitiesMagda Lesicka kept the baby, prosecutor Rob Hall later told Chilversapos trial. In April , Lesicka again discovered Chilvers was having an affair - with a female member of Ryanair cabin crew. Chilvers was promoted to Captain with the airline and he moved to Lanzarote for work. He showed, prosecutors would claim, aposlittle interest in the pregnancyapos. Cruel bully called fiancee a apossheepapos  James was born in September , and mother and son joined Chilvers in Lanzarote. But soon after that, Chilvers began to tell Lesicka that having the baby had taken his freedom away, and that he felt aposbetrayedapos and aposdisgustedapos with her. Magda Lesicka would do anything for James, including seeking to create a happy home le for him, eventhat meant accommodating Peter Chilvers’s attacks on her personality and decision-making, Mr Hall said. Chilvers throttled Lesicka a number of times. He regularly subjected her to degrading acts, to which she felt she had no choice but to consent. He would pull out hairs from his head and put them in her mouth, before ordering her to aposswallowapos. And he aposmentally demeanedapos her, calling her a apossheepapos and describing himself as a apossheep ownerapos. Later Lesicka learned that despite his promises to end his affair, Chilvers had carried on with it. But when Lesicka suggested that she and James shouldto the UK from Lanzarote, Chilvers told her: If you ever try and run away and hide, I will find you and will kill you.  Hethreatened her thatthe issue of who James should live with after they separated ever went to court, he would have more money than her, he would get better lawyers than her and he would make sure that she never saw James again, Rob Hall told Chilvers trial. In July , the young family moved to Wythenshawe, on a new-build estate close to Manchester Airport. By , Chilvers work base had become Liverpool Airport, so he regularly stayed in Wythenshawe with them, all the while continuing his affair. Later that year, Chilvers bought a home in Cheshire to aposlead a le awayapos from Lesicka, but problems continued. On the occasions when Magda Lesicka summoned up enough courage to talk to Peter Chilvers about the state of their relationship and her desire to end their relationship, he would manipulate her into carrying on, Mr Hall said. At one point in the car, Lesicka dared to confront Chilvers, telling him: You don’t love me. You don’t love James. You just love yourself.  Around that time, Lesicka started to confide with her colleagues about the abuse she suffered, and showed them bruises she suffered at Chilversapos hand. By August  their relationship was in pieces. In the week before Jamesapos death Chilvers went to solicitors to draw up a aposcohabitation contractapos, which stated Lesicka would have to pay £ a month to live with him, and she wouldnapost have any claim to the ownership of the house. He assaulted Lesicka in front of James after losing his temper, pushing her to the floor and sitting on her chest, before tickling her asit was a game. When Lesicka heard that the woman Chilvers had been having an affair with was moving to work from Manchester Airport, Chilvers became angry and threw her phone to the floor, smashing the screen. The lead-up to the tragedy In the days before he died, James went to stay with Chilversapos parents in the Lake District. Lesicka used the time to start making plans for a new le away from Chilvers. She researched rental properties, started to make notes about the abuse she had suffered, took pictures of her bruises, and told her manager at work of what was happening in her relationship. She also went to the police.  Officers planned to arrest Chilvers when he arrived back in Wythenshawe after flying a Ryanair service to Tenere. But when they told Lesicka of their plan, she was fearful of what would happen and begged officers to just log her complaint, rather than carry out the arrest. Chilvers would have been arrested on the day Lesicka went on to kill James. He was due to arrive back at Manchester Airport at .pm on August . As he was landing, Lesicka suffered a apossuddenapos mental breakdown. She stabbed their son to death in an upstairs bedroom at the house on Beaford Road and then tried to commit suicide. When Chilvers arrived back at Beaford Road at .pm, Lesicka fell into his arms, seriously injured.  He took her to hospital, unaware that James was fatally injured. It was only at the hospital that a concern was raised for the young boy. Police arrived at the house at about .am, and found the toddler dead. aposEgocentricapos pilot who blamed everyone but himself Officers were only able to speak to Lesicka about Jamesapos death two and a half months later, as she had originally been detained under the Mental Health Act. Later doctors agreed that Lesicka was suffering from aposan abnormality of mental ing which impaired her ability to understand her own conduct, form a rational judgement or exercise self-controlapos. On those grounds, Lesicka, who had not previously suffered from mental health problems, pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. On Facebook in September, Chilvers posted a series of pictures of his son, writing: Jamie, my beautul and wonderful darling. You would have been  today. We all miss you desperately. Two years since your murder and still nothing has been done. On this day, your birthday, I solemnly promise you that I will fight for justice for you darling. I will always love you and always think of you. aposAlways alwaysapos Daddy. But in the sentencing hearing this week, Judge Patrick Field QC told Chilvers he had treated Lesicka as his apospropertyapos.  I have detected no more than a hint of your remorse and I note that even a doctor describes you as egocentric, having a longing for appreciation, and a reduced ability to understand fully how your behaviour affects others, and that you seek to minimise what you have done wrong and seek to sht the blame to others, the judge told him. You apparently have a preoccupation with the injustice of it all. That attitude was on full public display when you gave evidence. Chilvers now has two other children with the cabin crew worker he was having an affair with. His barrister Mark Ford said that relationship shows a dferent side to the defendant, as it is apossupportiveapos, aposco-operativeapos and aposlovingapos.  Chilvers, the defence lawyer said, is aposdeeply traumatisedapos by the death of his son, frequently breaking into aposhysterical screamingapos. It is frankly impossible for anybody to comprehend the ordeal that Mr Chilvers and his family have undergone, Mr Ford said. He is, in short, a man on the edge, and he has been for over two years. The barrister appealed to the judge for Chilvers to be spared jail, because he has no previous convictions and is the aposprimary carerapos of his two children. But Judge Field said he had concluded aposwithout hesitationapos that only prison was justied. As Mr Ford put it, just a few years ago, Chilvers had the aposworld at his feetapos. Now he has lost his job, his freedom, and his young son. aposHe has taken everything from meapos As for Lesicka, in a statement from her jail cell, she described herself as feeling aposugly, worthless, defenceless, ashamed and guiltyapos. I have very little left in my le, she said. Her words were read to the court this week, giving her a voice for the first time as she gave evidence for the prosecution during Chilversaposs Manchester Crown Court trial for abusing her, and prepared a victim impact statement to be read on her behalf at his sentencing In the statement, Lesicka said: Itaposs hard to see myself as a victim given the tragic outcome. I know my le has been changed forever and there is nothing I can do change it back. I have the rest of my le to contemplate these events and it is a daunting prospect. When I started a relationship with Peter Chilvers I had absolutely no idea he would be the controlling monster I discovered him to be. It is important that the public understand what Peter Chilversaposs abuse did to me. It destroyed me. I have no idea how he achieved this and I will probably spend the rest of my le trying to work out how he turned the confident, ambitious me into what I am now. He broke me and I find it almost impossible to contemplate that I let this happen. Living with Peter became an exercise of walking on eggshells. The best way to describe the latter stages of the relationship is it became a power struggle. I tried to leave but he would not let me. I had no power. I tried to break away for the safety of James and myself. I failed because Peter would not release me. I failed because Peter had too much control over me. I lost all my self respect. My only goal was to get through another day.

story: NewsWoman loses  stone and  dress sizes after being humiliated on holiday from hellAimee Cumbers, , from Maldron, Essex, has shared her tips for keeping the weight off at Christmas - after feeling ashamed over how her weight held her back from enjoying a dream holidayShareCommentsByLouise Lazell:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsAimee Cumbers, from Maldon, has shared her incredible weight loss journey " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who was left humiliated after being banned from parasailing on holiday because she was too heavy has dropped six dress sizes. Aimee Cumbers, , from Essex, has gone from  stone and a size   to a size . She has slimmed down after realising her -stone frame was holding her back. But her incredible weight loss journey is the result of a huge effort after years of struggles to lose weight. Aimee told Essex Live she had struggled with her weight since she was a little girl, and over the years had tried every diet, shake, juice and trick in the book to try to shed the extra pounds. But it was always the same outcome - lose two stone, then gain more. She described herself as a secret eater. Aimee would buy herself sweets and treats to sneak to her bedroom and eat, hiding the evidence from her parents and lying about itthey found any wrappers. But everything changed after Aimee had a holiday which knocked her confidence to rock-bottom. The turning point was in  when Aimee sat on a plane to go on holiday and nearly couldnapost do her seatbelt up. Coming back from her trip, Aimee decided it was time to make a change. Within a year, she had dropped from a size  to size  after losing over seven stone. Now, she is sharing her story in the hope that she can encourage others to take the leap. Between  and , Aimee became more and more self-conscious about the way she looked after she started getting refused for events because of her weight. The worst memory of this was in Turkey , when she realised her seat belt nearly didnapost fit. She said: It happened a couple of times, I went to Turkey one time and the seat belt was quite tight. I just remember thinkingI get any bigger, I’m going to have to ask for an extension, which made me feel embarrassed as I had never been close to that point before.  No one should feel embarrassed to ask for one, but that’s how I felt personally. It was a turning point. Once Aimee landed, she was excited to do all the events they had planned. She said: Once I got to Turkey, we weaposre going to do all these activities like parasailing and I got refused. They said I had to weigh myself and I was too heavy. They just looked at me and said aposno, sheaposs not going onapos. I felt absolutely mortied. I was so embarrassed. That was it, I was self-conscious the whole time and I couldnapost do anything . My confidence was absolutely gone. It impacted on it in so many dferent ways. But it wasnapost just on holiday where Aimee was refused entry. I wasnapost allowed to do Jump Street. We had a party at work and I couldnapost do it because I was too heavy, she said. I looked online before I went and thought, I canapost go. I told them I couldnapost make it. It was just really upsetting, it was more the embarrassment and not wanting to say thataposs the case. Even just normal activities like shopping and eating out became a source of concern.  Aimee was even worried about going to restaurants to eat in public, in the fear that someone might see her and judge her. Shopping was a major ordeal, I couldnapost just go into Primark and pick up certain things. I had to try it on andI was going away it had to all be a body cover up. I just felt awful. Coming back from her holiday in , Aimeeaposs self-esteem had ebbed to an all time low. When her friends suggested joining Slimming World, she did it thinking it would fail like every other diet she had tried. A few of my friends were going and they said aposcome on Aimee, joinapos. I didnapost have much pressure because I had done it before and it hadnapost worked, she said. I had just got back from holiday and I was feeling bloated and I was looking back at pictures and thinking aposJesus, is that me apos After trying a few Slimming World groups, Aimee found the perfect one. She said: I was in the swing of it. I had support from my boyfriendaposs family and they said I could cook the meals. They were having them with me as well which really helped. My family were so supportive and thats what kept me on. Within a year, Aimee had lost just over seven stone, dropping six dress sizes. She has learnt to cook some amazing meals and met so many new friends at her group sessions. I feel like a dferent woman to the one who walked into Slimming World. It felt really good and to get smaller clothes I started noticing that I could walk into Primark and New Look.  Photographs really helped too. On Instagram you have so many people who are going through the same thing and are all so supportive. With hard work and determination, Aimee has kept the weight off since then, including another ten pounds. One of the toughest times of the year has always been Christmas time, which seems to revolve around food. The first Christmas was really dficult because itaposs just food everywhere and thereaposs temptation everywhere. Itaposs always good to have a day off and not over indulge. I remember the first Christmas I had after I joined Slimming World in October, I had eaten what I wanted. I had all the snacks, chocolate but after a few days I was so poorly. I got to Boxing Day and I was so poorly. Your body isnapost used to it anymore and your stomach has shrunk. I couldnapost believe I used to do that. One of the hardest parts, was the constant encouragement from other people to eat and drinkat Christmas time. It was a lot of pressure, it was all the aposcome on, itaposs Christmas!apos and aposyou have to!apos comments, she said. They didnapost understand it was important I didnapost go back to bad habits. You just canapost help not say: aposeat this, eat thatapos andyou say no it just gets worse. Itaposs a lot of pressure. Itaposs just the run up to Christmas with all the Christmas parties, the sweets, the selection boxes - it just revolves around food.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A young girl found an owl hiding inside her familyaposs Christmas tree while admiring all of their ornaments and lights.The tree was decorated with about a dozen owl ornaments when India Newman, , spotted the live bird tucked inside the branches. It may have been nesting there for two weeks before it was finally noticed. The terried child shouted Oh my gosh and then ran to her mum, Katie McBride Newman, in the dining room of the family home, telling her: Mama, that ornament scared me. After India burst into tears, Katie, who is a fan of owls, went to inspect the real Christmas tree, thinking her daughter had only been spooked by one of her bird ornaments. But the mum was shocked when she peered into the tree and the owl turned its head and looked back at her.Katie, from the US city of Newnan, Georgia, told CNN: [India] comes very dramatically into the dining room and goes, aposMama, that ornament scared meapos.Then she bursts into tears. Describing the moment she found the bird on December , she added: Iaposm like, aposOh, thataposs a real owlapos.  By then, India - still in tears - had disappeared into another room. The family left their windows and doors open, hoping the owl would fly out on its own. However, when they woke up the next morning it was still there.  When they called the Chattahoochee Nature Center, a worker advised them to put out some raw chicken in case the owl hadnapost eaten for days. The worker came round to the house last Saturday and caught the bird, identying it as an eastern screech owl. Because the owl was thin, the worker believed it had been in the tree since the family bought it from a shop in late November.
